encodingDesc.p: This letter contains references to the following:

div.p:
Your letter has come and, although I think seventy dollars rather little for the number of poems you have, I suppose I must accede to it. But I should like to make a protest, not only on my own account but on account of your other contributors, which is that you should pay your regular rate per page, whatever that may be, no matter how many pages a person is given. What is the advantage for any poet to have a number of poems, if he loses money by it? Most of these young poets need every penny they can get, and they get very little. You accept their poems and hold them up sometimes for over a year, making it impossible for them to send them anywhere else; and yet you do not pay them until the poems are published. I do think that is a great mistake. As far as I am concerned, you get it back in the advertising, for I always insist upon the publishers advertising everything in your pages. We have got our New Poetry Series in your magazine
now, and I shall make Macmillan put in “Six French Poets” this Autumn. I do think it is a mistake, Harriet, and I wish you would consider it, that is all. I repeat I think your pro rata page should be pro rata, no matter how many pages one person has.
Couldn’t you make it August, instead of September? September seems awfully far away, but if you cannot make it August, I will accept September, and be thankful.

By the way, I have read “Spoon River” from cover to cover. I quite agree with you, it is one of the most remarkable books ever published in this country. As a novel, it is, as far as I know, unsurpassed. I shall be very interested to see what Mr. Masters will attempt next. His knowledge of humanity is extraordinarily wide and clear, and these little, headed-up poems give an impression of reality which I do not remember ever having felt so vividly before.
I am sorry McClurg would only take twelve copies. I don’t see why he cares how many he takes, so long as he only pays for what he sells. Do stir people up to buy some copies, if you can.
